B: article_title: Sleep and Obesity article Sleep disturbance and obesity risk section Obstructive sleep apnea
D: system_role: You are an expert at science communication.
F: text:
Sleep and Obesity article Sleep disturbance and obesity risk section Obstructive sleep apnea

Sleep loss occurs not only as a result of habitual behavior, but also in presence of pathological conditions associated with disturbed sleep, like obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The increase in both the prevalence and the severity of obesity has translated into an increase in the prevalence of obesity-related comorbidities including OSA. The prevalence of OSA in the US adult population has been estimated to be 24% in men and 9% in women [49] but is increased in severe obesity by up to 93.6% among men and 73.5% among women [50].
OSA is characterized by recurrent episodes of complete or partial obstruction of the upper airway during sleep associated with progressive respiratory effort to overcome the obstruction. These events lead to cortical micro-arousals and oxygen desaturation and overall sleep fragmentation, chronic sleep loss, and increased sympathetic nervous activity [51]. Whether the sleep fragmentation secondary to OSA results in similar pathophysiological mechanisms like sleep deprivation [52] has not been well studied.
Although compelling evidence shows that obesity predisposes to OSA and that losing weight results in OSA improvement, recent studies suggest that OSA itself may cause weight gain. If sleep deprivation appears to be a risk factor for obesity, the sleep fragmentation, overall sleep loss, and daytime sleepiness associated with OSA could similarly favor weight gain, which then further worsens OSA. According to this new paradigm, OSA would cause a complex interaction of behavioral changes, leptin resistance, and increased ghrelin levels leading to decreased physical activity and/or an increase in unhealthier eating habits. A few studies have previously suggested that increased severity of OSA [53,54] and excessive daytime sleepiness [55] are associated with decreased physical activity by self-report. A recent cross-sectional study in a small sample of clinic patients [56] found that increased OSA severity was associated with objectively measured decreased physical activity, after controlling for age, sex, and daytime sleepiness. The small sample size and the study design are obvious limitations and, therefore, this study does not unequivocally prove that OSA leads to decreased physical activity but suggests a mechanism worth exploring.
Alternatively, OSA could directly affect appetite regulation and ultimately result in increased caloric intake. Studies in patients with OSA and similarly obese controls showed that those with OSA had gained weight in the year preceding the diagnosis [57] and had higher leptin levels than expected based on their percentage body fat [5760] suggesting that OSA is associated with greater resistance to the weight-reducing effect of leptin than obesity alone. Multiple intervention studies in adults demonstrated a decrease in leptin levels in patients treated with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) [58,6165]. Night-time levels of ghrelin are increased in obese patients [66]. One study showed that 2 days of CPAP treatment were sufficient to significantly decrease ghrelin levels in patients with OSA [65].
In addition to causing sleep fragmentation and overall sleep loss, OSA also involves respiratory distress, hypoxia, and hypercapnia with the result of an increase in sympathetic nervous activity. Leptin secretion in OSA could be triggered by hypoxia [67,68], whereas ghrelin release could be related to sympathetic activation [69].
Appetite regulation in OSA and the effect of OSA treatment are still the subject of a recent investigation. Eun et al. [44] showed that surgical treatment of OSA leads to a decrease in leptin levels in the absence of weight change, independently of the severity of OSA. Ursavas et al. [45] measured significantly higher serum ghrelin levels in 55 patients with newly diagnosed OSA compared with nonapneic age-matched and BMI-matched participants, despite no difference in total sleeping time and sleep efficiency. Ghrelin levels correlated with the apnea-hypoxia index (AHI) and with subjective sleepiness. In this study, adipokines such as leptin, adiponectin, and resistin did not differ between the groups.
The published studies have not measured subjective ratings of hunger, food preferences, or food intake. One of the abnormalities of sleep architecture seen in OSA is reduced slow wave sleep (SWS) or deep sleep. Preliminary data showed that experimental suppression of SWS without affecting sleep duration in young healthy adults leads to increased hunger for calorie dense foods with high carbohydrate content particularly in the afternoon and evening hours [70]. In parallel with these early findings in the adults, a very recent study in 59-year-old obese children with and without OSA demonstrate that children with OSA ate 2.2 times more fast food and less healthy food such as fruits and vegetables, and they were 4.2 times less likely to be involved in organized sports [71]. Furthermore, OSA severity positively correlated with plasma ghrelin levels [71].

There is a treatment called continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) that can help with OSA. Studies have shown that it can also help with appetite control. Children with OSA may be more likely to eat unhealthy foods and less likely to be involved in sports.

B: article_title: Sleep and Obesity article Sleep disturbance and obesity risk section Obstructive sleep apnea
D: system_role: You are an expert at science communication.
F: text:
Sleep and Obesity article Sleep disturbance and obesity risk section Obstructive sleep apnea

Sleep loss occurs not only as a result of habitual behavior, but also in presence of pathological conditions associated with disturbed sleep, like obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The increase in both the prevalence and the severity of obesity has translated into an increase in the prevalence of obesity-related comorbidities including OSA. The prevalence of OSA in the US adult population has been estimated to be 24% in men and 9% in women [49] but is increased in severe obesity by up to 93.6% among men and 73.5% among women [50].
OSA is characterized by recurrent episodes of complete or partial obstruction of the upper airway during sleep associated with progressive respiratory effort to overcome the obstruction. These events lead to cortical micro-arousals and oxygen desaturation and overall sleep fragmentation, chronic sleep loss, and increased sympathetic nervous activity [51]. Whether the sleep fragmentation secondary to OSA results in similar pathophysiological mechanisms like sleep deprivation [52] has not been well studied.
Although compelling evidence shows that obesity predisposes to OSA and that losing weight results in OSA improvement, recent studies suggest that OSA itself may cause weight gain. If sleep deprivation appears to be a risk factor for obesity, the sleep fragmentation, overall sleep loss, and daytime sleepiness associated with OSA could similarly favor weight gain, which then further worsens OSA. According to this new paradigm, OSA would cause a complex interaction of behavioral changes, leptin resistance, and increased ghrelin levels leading to decreased physical activity and/or an increase in unhealthier eating habits. A few studies have previously suggested that increased severity of OSA [53,54] and excessive daytime sleepiness [55] are associated with decreased physical activity by self-report. A recent cross-sectional study in a small sample of clinic patients [56] found that increased OSA severity was associated with objectively measured decreased physical activity, after controlling for age, sex, and daytime sleepiness. The small sample size and the study design are obvious limitations and, therefore, this study does not unequivocally prove that OSA leads to decreased physical activity but suggests a mechanism worth exploring.
Alternatively, OSA could directly affect appetite regulation and ultimately result in increased caloric intake. Studies in patients with OSA and similarly obese controls showed that those with OSA had gained weight in the year preceding the diagnosis [57] and had higher leptin levels than expected based on their percentage body fat [5760] suggesting that OSA is associated with greater resistance to the weight-reducing effect of leptin than obesity alone. Multiple intervention studies in adults demonstrated a decrease in leptin levels in patients treated with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) [58,6165]. Night-time levels of ghrelin are increased in obese patients [66]. One study showed that 2 days of CPAP treatment were sufficient to significantly decrease ghrelin levels in patients with OSA [65].
In addition to causing sleep fragmentation and overall sleep loss, OSA also involves respiratory distress, hypoxia, and hypercapnia with the result of an increase in sympathetic nervous activity. Leptin secretion in OSA could be triggered by hypoxia [67,68], whereas ghrelin release could be related to sympathetic activation [69].
Appetite regulation in OSA and the effect of OSA treatment are still the subject of a recent investigation. Eun et al. [44] showed that surgical treatment of OSA leads to a decrease in leptin levels in the absence of weight change, independently of the severity of OSA. Ursavas et al. [45] measured significantly higher serum ghrelin levels in 55 patients with newly diagnosed OSA compared with nonapneic age-matched and BMI-matched participants, despite no difference in total sleeping time and sleep efficiency. Ghrelin levels correlated with the apnea-hypoxia index (AHI) and with subjective sleepiness. In this study, adipokines such as leptin, adiponectin, and resistin did not differ between the groups.
The published studies have not measured subjective ratings of hunger, food preferences, or food intake. One of the abnormalities of sleep architecture seen in OSA is reduced slow wave sleep (SWS) or deep sleep. Preliminary data showed that experimental suppression of SWS without affecting sleep duration in young healthy adults leads to increased hunger for calorie dense foods with high carbohydrate content particularly in the afternoon and evening hours [70]. In parallel with these early findings in the adults, a very recent study in 59-year-old obese children with and without OSA demonstrate that children with OSA ate 2.2 times more fast food and less healthy food such as fruits and vegetables, and they were 4.2 times less likely to be involved in organized sports [71]. Furthermore, OSA severity positively correlated with plasma ghrelin levels [71].

Your audience is for people without a science background
R: simple summary:
```
Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a condition that can make it hard to sleep well. It affects up to 24% of men and 9% of women in the US. OSA is linked to being overweight, which can make it worse. OSA can make you less active and make you want to eat unhealthy foods. It can also make you want to eat more food. There is a treatment for OSA called continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) that can help you feel less hungry and more full. Some early research suggests that OSA might make you want to eat more foods that have a lot of calories and carbohydrates, especially in the afternoon and evening.```

Your audience consists of seniors
AD: seniors: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a common sleep disorder that affects a significant portion of the population, including up to 24% of men and 9% of women in the US. OSA is linked to obesity, which can worsen the condition and lead to decreased physical activity and unhealthy eating habits. This can be particularly relevant for seniors who may already be struggling with maintaining a healthy lifestyle. Treatment of OSA, such as with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), has been shown to decrease levels of the hunger hormone ghrelin and increase levels of the satiety hormone leptin. Preliminary data suggests that OSA may cause increased hunger for calorie-dense foods with high carbohydrate content, particularly in the afternoon and evening hours. It is important for seniors to be aware of the potential impact of OSA on their health and to seek appropriate treatment if necessary.

Your audience is for people without a science background
R: simple summary:
Did you know that a sleep disorder called obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) can cause sleep problems and weight gain? OSA is common in the US, affecting around 24% of men and 9% of women. However, it's even more common in people with severe obesity, affecting up to 93.6% of men and 73.5% of women. 

OSA happens when the upper airway is blocked during sleep, causing breathing problems and making it hard to get a good night's sleep. This can lead to feeling tired during the day and can make it harder to be active and eat healthily. 

Studies have shown that OSA can cause weight gain, and weight gain can make OSA worse. This can create a cycle that's hard to break. OSA can also affect hormones that control appetite, making it harder to resist unhealthy foods. 

Researchers are still studying how OSA affects appetite and how treating OSA can help. Some studies have shown that treating OSA with a machine called continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) can help reduce appetite hormones and improve sleep. 

While more research is needed, it's important to know that OSA can affect sleep and weight, and treating OSA can help improve both.

Appetite regulation in OSA and the effect of OSA treatment are still the subject of a recent investigation. Eun et al. [44] showed that surgical treatment of OSA leads to a decrease in leptin levels in the absence of weight change, independently of the severity of OSA. Ursavas et al. [45] measured significantly higher serum ghrelin levels in 55 patients with newly diagnosed OSA compared with nonapneic age-matched and BMI-matched participants, despite no difference in total sleeping time and sleep efficiency. Ghrelin levels correlated with the apnea-hypoxia index (AHI) and with subjective sleepiness. In this study, adipokines such as leptin, adiponectin, and resistin did not differ between the groups.
The published studies have not measured subjective ratings of hunger, food preferences, or food intake. One of the abnormalities of sleep architecture seen in OSA is reduced slow wave sleep (SWS) or deep sleep. Preliminary data showed that experimental suppression of SWS without affecting sleep duration in young healthy adults leads to increased hunger for calorie dense foods with high carbohydrate content particularly in the afternoon and evening hours [70]. In parallel with these early findings in the adults, a very recent study in 59-year-old obese children with and without OSA demonstrate that children with OSA ate 2.2 times more fast food and less healthy food such as fruits and vegetables, and they were 4.2 times less likely to be involved in organized sports [71]. Furthermore, OSA severity positively correlated with plasma ghrelin levels [71].

Your audience is for people without a science background
R: simple summary: Hey, did you know that a sleep disorder called obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) can cause weight gain and increase the risk of health problems related to obesity? OSA is quite common, affecting about 24% of men and 9% of women in the US. It happens when your airway gets blocked during sleep, which can lead to poor sleep quality, feeling tired during the day, and increased stress. Studies suggest that OSA could make you less active and more likely to eat unhealthy foods. It could also affect your appetite and make you eat more calories. People with OSA tend to gain weight before they get diagnosed, and their hormones that control appetite are often out of balance. Treatment with a machine called continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) can help balance these hormones and improve sleep quality. Scientists are still studying how OSA affects appetite and how treatment can help.

B: article_title: Sleep and Obesity article Sleep disturbance and obesity risk section Obstructive sleep apnea
D: system_role: You are an expert at science communication.
F: text:
Sleep and Obesity article Sleep disturbance and obesity risk section Obstructive sleep apnea

Sleep loss occurs not only as a result of habitual behavior, but also in presence of pathological conditions associated with disturbed sleep, like obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The increase in both the prevalence and the severity of obesity has translated into an increase in the prevalence of obesity-related comorbidities including OSA. The prevalence of OSA in the US adult population has been estimated to be 24% in men and 9% in women [49] but is increased in severe obesity by up to 93.6% among men and 73.5% among women [50].
OSA is characterized by recurrent episodes of complete or partial obstruction of the upper airway during sleep associated with progressive respiratory effort to overcome the obstruction. These events lead to cortical micro-arousals and oxygen desaturation and overall sleep fragmentation, chronic sleep loss, and increased sympathetic nervous activity [51]. Whether the sleep fragmentation secondary to OSA results in similar pathophysiological mechanisms like sleep deprivation [52] has not been well studied.
Although compelling evidence shows that obesity predisposes to OSA and that losing weight results in OSA improvement, recent studies suggest that OSA itself may cause weight gain. If sleep deprivation appears to be a risk factor for obesity, the sleep fragmentation, overall sleep loss, and daytime sleepiness associated with OSA could similarly favor weight gain, which then further worsens OSA. According to this new paradigm, OSA would cause a complex interaction of behavioral changes, leptin resistance, and increased ghrelin levels leading to decreased physical activity and/or an increase in unhealthier eating habits. A few studies have previously suggested that increased severity of OSA [53,54] and excessive daytime sleepiness [55] are associated with decreased physical activity by self-report. A recent cross-sectional study in a small sample of clinic patients [56] found that increased OSA severity was associated with objectively measured decreased physical activity, after controlling for age, sex, and daytime sleepiness. The small sample size and the study design are obvious limitations and, therefore, this study does not unequivocally prove that OSA leads to decreased physical activity but suggests a mechanism worth exploring.
Alternatively, OSA could directly affect appetite regulation and ultimately result in increased caloric intake. Studies in patients with OSA and similarly obese controls showed that those with OSA had gained weight in the year preceding the diagnosis [57] and had higher leptin levels than expected based on their percentage body fat [5760] suggesting that OSA is associated with greater resistance to the weight-reducing effect of leptin than obesity alone. Multiple intervention studies in adults demonstrated a decrease in leptin levels in patients treated with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) [58,6165]. Night-time levels of ghrelin are increased in obese patients [66]. One study showed that 2 days of CPAP treatment were sufficient to significantly decrease ghrelin levels in patients with OSA [65].
In addition to causing sleep fragmentation and overall sleep loss, OSA also involves respiratory distress, hypoxia, and hypercapnia with the result of an increase in sympathetic nervous activity. Leptin secretion in OSA could be triggered by hypoxia [67,68], whereas ghrelin release could be related to sympathetic activation [69].
Appetite regulation in OSA and the effect of OSA treatment are still the subject of a recent investigation. Eun et al. [44] showed that surgical treatment of OSA leads to a decrease in leptin levels in the absence of weight change, independently of the severity of OSA. Ursavas et al. [45] measured significantly higher serum ghrelin levels in 55 patients with newly diagnosed OSA compared with nonapneic age-matched and BMI-matched participants, despite no difference in total sleeping time and sleep efficiency. Ghrelin levels correlated with the apnea-hypoxia index (AHI) and with subjective sleepiness. In this study, adipokines such as leptin, adiponectin, and resistin did not differ between the groups.
The published studies have not measured subjective ratings of hunger, food preferences, or food intake. One of the abnormalities of sleep architecture seen in OSA is reduced slow wave sleep (SWS) or deep sleep. Preliminary data showed that experimental suppression of SWS without affecting sleep duration in young healthy adults leads to increased hunger for calorie dense foods with high carbohydrate content particularly in the afternoon and evening hours [70]. In parallel with these early findings in the adults, a very recent study in 59-year-old obese children with and without OSA demonstrate that children with OSA ate 2.2 times more fast food and less healthy food such as fruits and vegetables, and they were 4.2 times less likely to be involved in organized sports [71]. Furthermore, OSA severity positively correlated with plasma ghrelin levels [71].

J: summary: Did you know that obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is associated with both obesity and increased risk of obesity-related comorbidities? In the US adult population, the prevalence of OSA is estimated to be 24% in men and 9% in women, but it can increase up to 93.6% among men and 73.5% among women with severe obesity. OSA is characterized by recurrent episodes of upper airway obstruction during sleep, leading to cortical micro-arousals, oxygen desaturation, and sleep fragmentation, among other things. Surprisingly, recent studies suggest that OSA itself may cause weight gain, and not just obesity predisposing to OSA. This is because the sleep fragmentation, daytime sleepiness, and overall sleep loss associated with OSA could similarly favor weight gain, leading to a complex interaction of behavioral changes, leptin resistance, and increased ghrelin levels, ultimately resulting in decreased physical activity and/or an increase in unhealthier eating habits. Studies have also shown that OSA could directly affect appetite regulation and lead to increased caloric intake. OSA treatment, such as surgical treatment or continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), has been shown to decrease leptin and ghrelin levels and improve appetite regulation. However, the effect of OSA treatment on subjective ratings of hunger, food preferences, or food intake is yet to be measured.

It's more common in people who are overweight. In fact, up to 93.6% of severely obese men and 73.5% of severely obese women have sleep apnea. Sleep apnea can make you feel tired during the day and can cause you to gain weight. It can also make it harder to control your appetite and make you want to eat more. But there are treatments that can help, like surgery or a machine called CPAP. These treatments can help you sleep better and control your appetite.

J: summary:
Hey, did you know that there is a strong link between sleep and obesity? A medical condition called obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) can cause sleep disturbance and increase the risk of obesity. In the US adult population, the prevalence of OSA is estimated to be 24% in men and 9% in women, but it can increase up to 93.6% among men and 73.5% among women with severe obesity. 

OSA is characterized by episodes of obstruction of the upper airway during sleep, leading to sleep fragmentation, chronic sleep loss, and increased sympathetic nervous activity. Interestingly, recent studies suggest that OSA itself may cause weight gain, as it can affect appetite regulation and result in increased caloric intake. 

Studies have shown that those with OSA had gained weight in the year preceding the diagnosis and had higher leptin levels than expected based on their body fat percentage, suggesting that OSA is associated with greater resistance to the weight-reducing effect of leptin than obesity alone. However, multiple intervention studies in adults demonstrated a decrease in leptin levels in patients treated with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). 

In addition to causing sleep fragmentation and overall sleep loss, OSA also involves respiratory distress, hypoxia, and hypercapnia, leading to an increase in sympathetic nervous activity. Leptin secretion in OSA could be triggered by hypoxia, whereas ghrelin release could be related to sympathetic activation. 

The published studies have not measured subjective ratings of hunger, food preferences, or food intake. However, early findings showed that experimental suppression of deep sleep leads to increased hunger for calorie-dense foods with high carbohydrate content, particularly in the afternoon and evening hours. Furthermore, a recent study in obese children with and without OSA demonstrated that children with OSA ate 2.2 times more fast food and less healthy food such as fruits and vegetables, and they were 4.2 times less likely to be involved in organized sports. OSA severity positively correlated with plasma ghrelin levels in these children. 

Overall, these findings suggest that OSA may cause a complex interaction of behavioral changes, leptin resistance, and increased ghrelin levels leading to decreased physical activity and/or an increase in unhealthier eating habits.

R: simple summary:
Hey, did you know that not getting enough sleep can lead to weight gain? A medical condition called obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) can cause sleep problems and increase the risk of obesity. In the US, about 1 in 4 men and 1 in 10 women have OSA, but it's even more common in people who are severely overweight. 

OSA happens when your airway gets blocked during sleep, which can make it hard to breathe and wake you up. This can make it hard to get a good night's sleep and can make your body more stressed. Recent studies suggest that OSA can also make you gain weight by making you feel more hungry and making it harder for your body to burn calories. 

Studies have shown that people with OSA often gain weight before they're diagnosed, and they have higher levels of a hormone called leptin, which is supposed to help you feel full. But when people with OSA use a special machine to help them breathe at night, their leptin levels go down. 

OSA can also make you feel more stressed, which can make it harder to eat healthy and exercise. Some studies have shown that people who don't get enough deep sleep are more likely to crave unhealthy foods, especially in the afternoon and evening. And in kids who are overweight, those with OSA eat more fast food and less healthy food, and they're less likely to play sports. 

Overall, these findings suggest that OSA can make it harder to sleep well, feel full, and make healthy choices.

Your audience consists of seniors
AD: seniors:
Did you know that there is a strong link between sleep and obesity? Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a medical condition that can cause sleep disturbance and increase the risk of obesity. OSA is prevalent in the US adult population, with estimates of up to 24% in men and 9% in women, but it can increase up to 93.6% among men and 73.5% among women with severe obesity. 

OSA is characterized by episodes of obstruction of the upper airway during sleep, leading to sleep fragmentation, chronic sleep loss, and increased sympathetic nervous activity. Recent studies suggest that OSA itself may cause weight gain, as it can affect appetite regulation and result in increased caloric intake. 

These findings are relevant for seniors as they may be at a higher risk of developing OSA due to age-related changes in the upper airway. Furthermore, OSA can lead to decreased physical activity and/or an increase in unhealthier eating habits, which can exacerbate age-related health issues. It is important for seniors to be aware of the link between sleep and obesity and to seek medical attention if they suspect they may have OSA.

B: article_title: Sleep and Obesity article Sleep disturbance and obesity risk section Obstructive sleep apnea
D: system_role: You are an expert at science communication.
F: text:
Sleep and Obesity article Sleep disturbance and obesity risk section Obstructive sleep apnea

Sleep loss occurs not only as a result of habitual behavior, but also in presence of pathological conditions associated with disturbed sleep, like obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The increase in both the prevalence and the severity of obesity has translated into an increase in the prevalence of obesity-related comorbidities including OSA. The prevalence of OSA in the US adult population has been estimated to be 24% in men and 9% in women [49] but is increased in severe obesity by up to 93.6% among men and 73.5% among women [50].
OSA is characterized by recurrent episodes of complete or partial obstruction of the upper airway during sleep associated with progressive respiratory effort to overcome the obstruction. These events lead to cortical micro-arousals and oxygen desaturation and overall sleep fragmentation, chronic sleep loss, and increased sympathetic nervous activity [51]. Whether the sleep fragmentation secondary to OSA results in similar pathophysiological mechanisms like sleep deprivation [52] has not been well studied.
Although compelling evidence shows that obesity predisposes to OSA and that losing weight results in OSA improvement, recent studies suggest that OSA itself may cause weight gain. If sleep deprivation appears to be a risk factor for obesity, the sleep fragmentation, overall sleep loss, and daytime sleepiness associated with OSA could similarly favor weight gain, which then further worsens OSA. According to this new paradigm, OSA would cause a complex interaction of behavioral changes, leptin resistance, and increased ghrelin levels leading to decreased physical activity and/or an increase in unhealthier eating habits. A few studies have previously suggested that increased severity of OSA [53,54] and excessive daytime sleepiness [55] are associated with decreased physical activity by self-report. A recent cross-sectional study in a small sample of clinic patients [56] found that increased OSA severity was associated with objectively measured decreased physical activity, after controlling for age, sex, and daytime sleepiness. The small sample size and the study design are obvious limitations and, therefore, this study does not unequivocally prove that OSA leads to decreased physical activity but suggests a mechanism worth exploring.
Alternatively, OSA could directly affect appetite regulation and ultimately result in increased caloric intake. Studies in patients with OSA and similarly obese controls showed that those with OSA had gained weight in the year preceding the diagnosis [57] and had higher leptin levels than expected based on their percentage body fat [5760] suggesting that OSA is associated with greater resistance to the weight-reducing effect of leptin than obesity alone. Multiple intervention studies in adults demonstrated a decrease in leptin levels in patients treated with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) [58,6165]. Night-time levels of ghrelin are increased in obese patients [66]. One study showed that 2 days of CPAP treatment were sufficient to significantly decrease ghrelin levels in patients with OSA [65].
In addition to causing sleep fragmentation and overall sleep loss, OSA also involves respiratory distress, hypoxia, and hypercapnia with the result of an increase in sympathetic nervous activity. Leptin secretion in OSA could be triggered by hypoxia [67,68], whereas ghrelin release could be related to sympathetic activation [69].
Appetite regulation in OSA and the effect of OSA treatment are still the subject of a recent investigation. Eun et al. [44] showed that surgical treatment of OSA leads to a decrease in leptin levels in the absence of weight change, independently of the severity of OSA. Ursavas et al. [45] measured significantly higher serum ghrelin levels in 55 patients with newly diagnosed OSA compared with nonapneic age-matched and BMI-matched participants, despite no difference in total sleeping time and sleep efficiency. Ghrelin levels correlated with the apnea-hypoxia index (AHI) and with subjective sleepiness. In this study, adipokines such as leptin, adiponectin, and resistin did not differ between the groups.
The published studies have not measured subjective ratings of hunger, food preferences, or food intake. One of the abnormalities of sleep architecture seen in OSA is reduced slow wave sleep (SWS) or deep sleep. Preliminary data showed that experimental suppression of SWS without affecting sleep duration in young healthy adults leads to increased hunger for calorie dense foods with high carbohydrate content particularly in the afternoon and evening hours [70]. In parallel with these early findings in the adults, a very recent study in 59-year-old obese children with and without OSA demonstrate that children with OSA ate 2.2 times more fast food and less healthy food such as fruits and vegetables, and they were 4.2 times less likely to be involved in organized sports [71]. Furthermore, OSA severity positively correlated with plasma ghrelin levels [71].

R: simple summary:
Hey, did you know that a condition called obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) can cause sleep problems and weight gain? It's pretty common, affecting about 24% of men and 9% of women in the US. But, it's even more common in people who are severely obese. 

OSA happens when your airway gets blocked during sleep, which can cause you to wake up and not get enough oxygen. This can lead to chronic sleep loss and increased stress on your body. 

Recent studies suggest that OSA itself may cause weight gain, and it could cause changes in your hormones that make you want to eat more. But, there are treatments available, like a machine called continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), that can help. 

Overall, scientists are still learning about how OSA affects your appetite and eating habits, but it's clear that it can have a big impact on your health.

Your audience is for people without a science background
R: simple summary: Did you know that having trouble breathing during sleep can increase the risk of gaining weight? Studies suggest that this can cause weight gain, decrease physical activity, and affect appetite regulation. This condition is called obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and it affects about 24% of men and 9% of women in the US. OSA happens when the airway gets blocked during sleep, which can cause sleep problems and make the body work harder to breathe. This can lead to feeling tired during the day and other health problems. It's important to prioritize healthy sleep habits to reduce the risk of OSA and other health issues related to being overweight.

B: article_title: Sleep and Obesity article Sleep disturbance and obesity risk section Obstructive sleep apnea
D: system_role: You are an expert at science communication.
F: text:
Sleep and Obesity article Sleep disturbance and obesity risk section Obstructive sleep apnea

Sleep loss occurs not only as a result of habitual behavior, but also in presence of pathological conditions associated with disturbed sleep, like obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The increase in both the prevalence and the severity of obesity has translated into an increase in the prevalence of obesity-related comorbidities including OSA. The prevalence of OSA in the US adult population has been estimated to be 24% in men and 9% in women [49] but is increased in severe obesity by up to 93.6% among men and 73.5% among women [50].
OSA is characterized by recurrent episodes of complete or partial obstruction of the upper airway during sleep associated with progressive respiratory effort to overcome the obstruction. These events lead to cortical micro-arousals and oxygen desaturation and overall sleep fragmentation, chronic sleep loss, and increased sympathetic nervous activity [51]. Whether the sleep fragmentation secondary to OSA results in similar pathophysiological mechanisms like sleep deprivation [52] has not been well studied.
Although compelling evidence shows that obesity predisposes to OSA and that losing weight results in OSA improvement, recent studies suggest that OSA itself may cause weight gain. If sleep deprivation appears to be a risk factor for obesity, the sleep fragmentation, overall sleep loss, and daytime sleepiness associated with OSA could similarly favor weight gain, which then further worsens OSA. According to this new paradigm, OSA would cause a complex interaction of behavioral changes, leptin resistance, and increased ghrelin levels leading to decreased physical activity and/or an increase in unhealthier eating habits. A few studies have previously suggested that increased severity of OSA [53,54] and excessive daytime sleepiness [55] are associated with decreased physical activity by self-report. A recent cross-sectional study in a small sample of clinic patients [56] found that increased OSA severity was associated with objectively measured decreased physical activity, after controlling for age, sex, and daytime sleepiness. The small sample size and the study design are obvious limitations and, therefore, this study does not unequivocally prove that OSA leads to decreased physical activity but suggests a mechanism worth exploring.
Alternatively, OSA could directly affect appetite regulation and ultimately result in increased caloric intake. Studies in patients with OSA and similarly obese controls showed that those with OSA had gained weight in the year preceding the diagnosis [57] and had higher leptin levels than expected based on their percentage body fat [5760] suggesting that OSA is associated with greater resistance to the weight-reducing effect of leptin than obesity alone. Multiple intervention studies in adults demonstrated a decrease in leptin levels in patients treated with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) [58,6165]. Night-time levels of ghrelin are increased in obese patients [66]. One study showed that 2 days of CPAP treatment were sufficient to significantly decrease ghrelin levels in patients with OSA [65].
In addition to causing sleep fragmentation and overall sleep loss, OSA also involves respiratory distress, hypoxia, and hypercapnia with the result of an increase in sympathetic nervous activity. Leptin secretion in OSA could be triggered by hypoxia [67,68], whereas ghrelin release could be related to sympathetic activation [69].
Appetite regulation in OSA and the effect of OSA treatment are still the subject of a recent investigation. Eun et al. [44] showed that surgical treatment of OSA leads to a decrease in leptin levels in the absence of weight change, independently of the severity of OSA. Ursavas et al. [45] measured significantly higher serum ghrelin levels in 55 patients with newly diagnosed OSA compared with nonapneic age-matched and BMI-matched participants, despite no difference in total sleeping time and sleep efficiency. Ghrelin levels correlated with the apnea-hypoxia index (AHI) and with subjective sleepiness. In this study, adipokines such as leptin, adiponectin, and resistin did not differ between the groups.
The published studies have not measured subjective ratings of hunger, food preferences, or food intake. One of the abnormalities of sleep architecture seen in OSA is reduced slow wave sleep (SWS) or deep sleep. Preliminary data showed that experimental suppression of SWS without affecting sleep duration in young healthy adults leads to increased hunger for calorie dense foods with high carbohydrate content particularly in the afternoon and evening hours [70]. In parallel with these early findings in the adults, a very recent study in 59-year-old obese children with and without OSA demonstrate that children with OSA ate 2.2 times more fast food and less healthy food such as fruits and vegetables, and they were 4.2 times less likely to be involved in organized sports [71]. Furthermore, OSA severity positively correlated with plasma ghrelin levels [71].

Studies suggest that OSA may cause weight gain through behavioral changes, leptin resistance, and increased ghrelin levels. OSA could also affect appetite regulation and result in increased caloric intake. However, losing weight can improve OSA. OSA is associated with decreased physical activity and increased sympathetic nervous activity. Treatment of OSA leads to a decrease in leptin levels and higher serum ghrelin levels. Children with OSA eat more fast food and less healthy food, and are less likely to be involved in organized sports. #sleep #obesity #health #science

R: simple summary: Sleep apnea, a condition where breathing is interrupted during sleep, can cause weight gain and obesity. This happens because sleep apnea affects our appetite and can make us eat more. However, losing weight can help improve sleep apnea. Children with sleep apnea tend to eat more unhealthy food and are less likely to participate in sports. Treatment for sleep apnea can help improve our hormones that control our appetite. #sleep #obesity #health

Furthermore, OSA severity positively correlated with plasma ghrelin levels [71].

B: article_title: Sleep and Obesity article Sleep disturbance and obesity risk section Poor sleep quality and excessive daytime sleepiness in the absence of obstructive sleep apnea
D: system_role: You are an expert at science communication.
F: text:
Sleep and Obesity article Sleep disturbance and obesity risk section Poor sleep quality and excessive daytime sleepiness in the absence of obstructive sleep apnea

Severe obesity appears to be associated with marked sleep disturbances, even in individuals who do not have OSA [7275]. Such sleep disturbances may equally predispose severely obese individuals to accumulate a sleep debt and may contribute to the dysregulation of appetite, limit the drive for physical activity, and further compromise weight maintenance.
Cross-sectional studies examining self-reported sleep quality have generally found that worse sleep quality is associated with higher BMI [7678], but the longitudinal studies have been scarce and the results inconsistent [79,80]. A more recent cross-sectional analysis in 400 women participants in the Sleep and Health in Women Study showed that not only sleep duration but also sleep quality, as determined by sleep efficiency and sleep architecture (specifically minutes of SWS, the deep restorative sleep) were inversely related to waist circumference, after adjusting for age, level of physical activity, smoking status, alcohol consumption and AHI [20]. Such associations were stronger in young women (age <50 years), suggesting that in older age the relationship between sleep quality and obesity may be less robust. The relationship between less time spent in SWS and central obesity could be mediated by a decrease in growth hormone level, which is secreted during SWS. Growth hormone deficiency is associated with visceral obesity, which can be reversed by growth hormone replacement [81,82]. Furthermore, a reduced amount of SWS leads to elevated cortisol levels, which favor central obesity [83].
In the Cardiovascular Health Epidemiology Study, which focused exclusively on AfricanAmericans, an impressive 50% or more of the participants surveyed reported suboptimal sleep duration and low-sleep quality as assessed by the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality scale [46]. In a multivariate analysis model, the effect of sleep duration on obesity risk was rather modest, with a significant association between lower sleep quality and increased BMI in women only, and this association was modulated by perceived stress level as measured by the Cohen scale.
A sex difference in the association between poor-sleep quality and obesity risk has been confirmed in a longitudinal study of 7000 Finnish adults, aged 4060 years. In women, sleep problems (difficulty initiating and maintaining sleep) predicted weight gain after 57 years. Moreover, there was a graded effect depending on the frequency of the sleep disturbances [47].
Nordin and Kaplan [48] examined the effect of sleep discontinuity on the development of obesity over a 30-year period in approximately 7000 middle-age adults. Sleep quality was self-reported and assessed by the question how often do you have any trouble getting to sleep or staying asleep? On the basis of the answers compared from the first and last observation, the participants were divided into four categories of sleep continuity, consistently good continuity, consistent discontinuity, impaired continuity (worsened over time), and improved continuity. The main outcome was the risk of transition to and from obesity. Consistent sleep discontinuity was associated with 70% risk of conversion to obesity after adjusting for confounding variables related to demographics, pain, lifestyle, and health including sleep duration. Both consistent sleep discontinuity and impaired sleep continuity reduced the chance for transitioning from obesity, thus increasing the risk of staying obese. The major limitation of the study was that sleep quality and anthropometrics were self-reported and the analysis could not control the presence of a sleep disorder like OSA, which could in part account for the risk of weight gain.

Reduced time spent in deep restorative sleep (SWS) is associated with central obesity, possibly due to decreased growth hormone levels and elevated cortisol levels. Sleep discontinuity increases the risk of obesity and reduces the chance of transitioning from obesity.

J: summary: Obesity and sleep quality are intricately linked, according to recent studies. Severe obesity is associated with sleep disturbances, which can lead to a dysregulation of appetite and physical activity, further compromising weight maintenance. Cross-sectional studies suggest that worse sleep quality is associated with higher BMI. However, longitudinal studies have been scarce and the results inconsistent. Some studies suggest that women are more affected by poor sleep quality, with frequent sleep disturbances predicting weight gain after 5-7 years. Sleep discontinuity is associated with a 70% risk of conversion to obesity and a reduced chance of transitioning from obesity. These findings highlight the importance of good quality sleep for maintaining a healthy weight. #obesity #sleepquality #healthresearch

B: article_title: Sleep and Obesity article Sleep disturbance and obesity risk section Poor sleep quality and excessive daytime sleepiness in the absence of obstructive sleep apnea
D: system_role: You are an expert at science communication.
F: text:
Sleep and Obesity article Sleep disturbance and obesity risk section Poor sleep quality and excessive daytime sleepiness in the absence of obstructive sleep apnea

Severe obesity appears to be associated with marked sleep disturbances, even in individuals who do not have OSA [7275]. Such sleep disturbances may equally predispose severely obese individuals to accumulate a sleep debt and may contribute to the dysregulation of appetite, limit the drive for physical activity, and further compromise weight maintenance.
Cross-sectional studies examining self-reported sleep quality have generally found that worse sleep quality is associated with higher BMI [7678], but the longitudinal studies have been scarce and the results inconsistent [79,80]. A more recent cross-sectional analysis in 400 women participants in the Sleep and Health in Women Study showed that not only sleep duration but also sleep quality, as determined by sleep efficiency and sleep architecture (specifically minutes of SWS, the deep restorative sleep) were inversely related to waist circumference, after adjusting for age, level of physical activity, smoking status, alcohol consumption and AHI [20]. Such associations were stronger in young women (age <50 years), suggesting that in older age the relationship between sleep quality and obesity may be less robust. The relationship between less time spent in SWS and central obesity could be mediated by a decrease in growth hormone level, which is secreted during SWS. Growth hormone deficiency is associated with visceral obesity, which can be reversed by growth hormone replacement [81,82]. Furthermore, a reduced amount of SWS leads to elevated cortisol levels, which favor central obesity [83].
In the Cardiovascular Health Epidemiology Study, which focused exclusively on AfricanAmericans, an impressive 50% or more of the participants surveyed reported suboptimal sleep duration and low-sleep quality as assessed by the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality scale [46]. In a multivariate analysis model, the effect of sleep duration on obesity risk was rather modest, with a significant association between lower sleep quality and increased BMI in women only, and this association was modulated by perceived stress level as measured by the Cohen scale.
A sex difference in the association between poor-sleep quality and obesity risk has been confirmed in a longitudinal study of 7000 Finnish adults, aged 4060 years. In women, sleep problems (difficulty initiating and maintaining sleep) predicted weight gain after 57 years. Moreover, there was a graded effect depending on the frequency of the sleep disturbances [47].
Nordin and Kaplan [48] examined the effect of sleep discontinuity on the development of obesity over a 30-year period in approximately 7000 middle-age adults. Sleep quality was self-reported and assessed by the question how often do you have any trouble getting to sleep or staying asleep? On the basis of the answers compared from the first and last observation, the participants were divided into four categories of sleep continuity, consistently good continuity, consistent discontinuity, impaired continuity (worsened over time), and improved continuity. The main outcome was the risk of transition to and from obesity. Consistent sleep discontinuity was associated with 70% risk of conversion to obesity after adjusting for confounding variables related to demographics, pain, lifestyle, and health including sleep duration. Both consistent sleep discontinuity and impaired sleep continuity reduced the chance for transitioning from obesity, thus increasing the risk of staying obese. The major limitation of the study was that sleep quality and anthropometrics were self-reported and the analysis could not control the presence of a sleep disorder like OSA, which could in part account for the risk of weight gain.

These findings highlight the importance of good sleep habits in maintaining a healthy weight."

Cross-sectional studies examining self-reported sleep quality have generally found that worse sleep quality is associated with higher BMI [7678], but the longitudinal studies have been scarce and the results inconsistent [79,80]. A more recent cross-sectional analysis in 400 women participants in the Sleep and Health in Women Study showed that not only sleep duration but also sleep quality, as determined by sleep efficiency and sleep architecture (specifically minutes of SWS, the deep restorative sleep) were inversely related to waist circumference, after adjusting for age, level of physical activity, smoking status, alcohol consumption and AHI [20]. Such associations were stronger in young women (age <50 years), suggesting that in older age the relationship between sleep quality and obesity may be less robust. The relationship between less time spent in SWS and central obesity could be mediated by a decrease in growth hormone level, which is secreted during SWS. Growth hormone deficiency is associated with visceral obesity, which can be reversed by growth hormone replacement [81,82]. Furthermore, a reduced amount of SWS leads to elevated cortisol levels, which favor central obesity [83].
In the Cardiovascular Health Epidemiology Study, which focused exclusively on AfricanAmericans, an impressive 50% or more of the participants surveyed reported suboptimal sleep duration and low-sleep quality as assessed by the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality scale [46]. In a multivariate analysis model, the effect of sleep duration on obesity risk was rather modest, with a significant association between lower sleep quality and increased BMI in women only, and this association was modulated by perceived stress level as measured by the Cohen scale.
A sex difference in the association between poor-sleep quality and obesity risk has been confirmed in a longitudinal study of 7000 Finnish adults, aged 4060 years. In women, sleep problems (difficulty initiating and maintaining sleep) predicted weight gain after 57 years. Moreover, there was a graded effect depending on the frequency of the sleep disturbances [47].
Nordin and Kaplan [48] examined the effect of sleep discontinuity on the development of obesity over a 30-year period in approximately 7000 middle-age adults. Sleep quality was self-reported and assessed by the question how often do you have any trouble getting to sleep or staying asleep? On the basis of the answers compared from the first and last observation, the participants were divided into four categories of sleep continuity, consistently good continuity, consistent discontinuity, impaired continuity (worsened over time), and improved continuity. The main outcome was the risk of transition to and from obesity. Consistent sleep discontinuity was associated with 70% risk of conversion to obesity after adjusting for confounding variables related to demographics, pain, lifestyle, and health including sleep duration. Both consistent sleep discontinuity and impaired sleep continuity reduced the chance for transitioning from obesity, thus increasing the risk of staying obese. The major limitation of the study was that sleep quality and anthropometrics were self-reported and the analysis could not control the presence of a sleep disorder like OSA, which could in part account for the risk of weight gain.

Your audience is for people without a science background
R: simple summary:
Hey, did you know that the quality of your sleep can affect your risk of becoming overweight? A recent study found that people who are severely overweight often have trouble sleeping, even if they don't have sleep apnea. Other studies have shown that people who report poor sleep quality tend to have a higher body mass index (BMI). However, this relationship may not be as strong in older people. 

When you don't get enough deep, restful sleep, your body produces more cortisol, which can lead to central obesity. In women, having trouble falling or staying asleep can lead to weight gain over time. And if you have a hard time sleeping consistently, you're more likely to become obese, even after taking into account things like your age, pain levels, lifestyle, and overall health. 

It's pretty amazing how much of an impact sleep quality can have on your risk of becoming overweight. So make sure you're getting enough good quality sleep!

In women, sleep problems (difficulty initiating and maintaining sleep) predicted weight gain after 57 years. Moreover, there was a graded effect depending on the frequency of the sleep disturbances [47].
Nordin and Kaplan [48] examined the effect of sleep discontinuity on the development of obesity over a 30-year period in approximately 7000 middle-age adults. Sleep quality was self-reported and assessed by the question how often do you have any trouble getting to sleep or staying asleep? On the basis of the answers compared from the first and last observation, the participants were divided into four categories of sleep continuity, consistently good continuity, consistent discontinuity, impaired continuity (worsened over time), and improved continuity. The main outcome was the risk of transition to and from obesity. Consistent sleep discontinuity was associated with 70% risk of conversion to obesity after adjusting for confounding variables related to demographics, pain, lifestyle, and health including sleep duration. Both consistent sleep discontinuity and impaired sleep continuity reduced the chance for transitioning from obesity, thus increasing the risk of staying obese. The major limitation of the study was that sleep quality and anthropometrics were self-reported and the analysis could not control the presence of a sleep disorder like OSA, which could in part account for the risk of weight gain.

Your audience is for people without a science background
R: simple summary: Did you know that not getting enough good quality sleep and feeling sleepy during the day can make you more likely to gain weight? Even if you don't have a condition called obstructive sleep apnea, being very overweight can make it harder to sleep well. Studies have shown that people who don't sleep well tend to have a higher body mass index (BMI), and that both the amount and quality of sleep are linked to having a bigger waistline, especially in young women. Interestingly, getting enough deep, restful sleep may help prevent central obesity (when you carry extra weight around your middle), possibly because it helps keep your growth hormone levels up. Women who have trouble sleeping are more likely to gain weight over time, and people who have trouble sleeping regularly are more likely to become obese.

Interestingly, the amount of deep restorative sleep (SWS) is also inversely related to central obesity, possibly due to a decrease in growth hormone level. In addition, there is a sex difference in the association between poor sleep quality and obesity risk, with sleep problems predicting weight gain after 5-7 years in women. B: article_title: Sleep and Obesity article Sleep disturbance and obesity risk section Poor sleep quality and excessive daytime sleepiness in the absence of obstructive sleep apnea
D: system_role: You are an expert at science communication.
F: text:
Sleep and Obesity article Sleep disturbance and obesity risk section Poor sleep quality and excessive daytime sleepiness in the absence of obstructive sleep apnea

Severe obesity appears to be associated with marked sleep disturbances, even in individuals who do not have OSA [7275]. Such sleep disturbances may equally predispose severely obese individuals to accumulate a sleep debt and may contribute to the dysregulation of appetite, limit the drive for physical activity, and further compromise weight maintenance.
Cross-sectional studies examining self-reported sleep quality have generally found that worse sleep quality is associated with higher BMI [7678], but the longitudinal studies have been scarce and the results inconsistent [79,80]. A more recent cross-sectional analysis in 400 women participants in the Sleep and Health in Women Study showed that not only sleep duration but also sleep quality, as determined by sleep efficiency and sleep architecture (specifically minutes of SWS, the deep restorative sleep) were inversely related to waist circumference, after adjusting for age, level of physical activity, smoking status, alcohol consumption and AHI [20]. Such associations were stronger in young women (age <50 years), suggesting that in older age the relationship between sleep quality and obesity may be less robust. The relationship between less time spent in SWS and central obesity could be mediated by a decrease in growth hormone level, which is secreted during SWS. Growth hormone deficiency is associated with visceral obesity, which can be reversed by growth hormone replacement [81,82]. Furthermore, a reduced amount of SWS leads to elevated cortisol levels, which favor central obesity [83].
In the Cardiovascular Health Epidemiology Study, which focused exclusively on AfricanAmericans, an impressive 50% or more of the participants surveyed reported suboptimal sleep duration and low-sleep quality as assessed by the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality scale [46]. In a multivariate analysis model, the effect of sleep duration on obesity risk was rather modest, with a significant association between lower sleep quality and increased BMI in women only, and this association was modulated by perceived stress level as measured by the Cohen scale.
A sex difference in the association between poor-sleep quality and obesity risk has been confirmed in a longitudinal study of 7000 Finnish adults, aged 4060 years. In women, sleep problems (difficulty initiating and maintaining sleep) predicted weight gain after 57 years. Moreover, there was a graded effect depending on the frequency of the sleep disturbances [47].
Nordin and Kaplan [48] examined the effect of sleep discontinuity on the development of obesity over a 30-year period in approximately 7000 middle-age adults. Sleep quality was self-reported and assessed by the question how often do you have any trouble getting to sleep or staying asleep? On the basis of the answers compared from the first and last observation, the participants were divided into four categories of sleep continuity, consistently good continuity, consistent discontinuity, impaired continuity (worsened over time), and improved continuity. The main outcome was the risk of transition to and from obesity. Consistent sleep discontinuity was associated with 70% risk of conversion to obesity after adjusting for confounding variables related to demographics, pain, lifestyle, and health including sleep duration. Both consistent sleep discontinuity and impaired sleep continuity reduced the chance for transitioning from obesity, thus increasing the risk of staying obese. The major limitation of the study was that sleep quality and anthropometrics were self-reported and the analysis could not control the presence of a sleep disorder like OSA, which could in part account for the risk of weight gain.

B: article_title: Sleep and Obesity article Sleep disturbance and obesity risk section Poor sleep quality and excessive daytime sleepiness in the absence of obstructive sleep apnea
D: system_role: You are an expert at science communication.
F: text:
Sleep and Obesity article Sleep disturbance and obesity risk section Poor sleep quality and excessive daytime sleepiness in the absence of obstructive sleep apnea

Severe obesity appears to be associated with marked sleep disturbances, even in individuals who do not have OSA [7275]. Such sleep disturbances may equally predispose severely obese individuals to accumulate a sleep debt and may contribute to the dysregulation of appetite, limit the drive for physical activity, and further compromise weight maintenance.
Cross-sectional studies examining self-reported sleep quality have generally found that worse sleep quality is associated with higher BMI [7678], but the longitudinal studies have been scarce and the results inconsistent [79,80]. A more recent cross-sectional analysis in 400 women participants in the Sleep and Health in Women Study showed that not only sleep duration but also sleep quality, as determined by sleep efficiency and sleep architecture (specifically minutes of SWS, the deep restorative sleep) were inversely related to waist circumference, after adjusting for age, level of physical activity, smoking status, alcohol consumption and AHI [20]. Such associations were stronger in young women (age <50 years), suggesting that in older age the relationship between sleep quality and obesity may be less robust. The relationship between less time spent in SWS and central obesity could be mediated by a decrease in growth hormone level, which is secreted during SWS. Growth hormone deficiency is associated with visceral obesity, which can be reversed by growth hormone replacement [81,82]. Furthermore, a reduced amount of SWS leads to elevated cortisol levels, which favor central obesity [83].
In the Cardiovascular Health Epidemiology Study, which focused exclusively on AfricanAmericans, an impressive 50% or more of the participants surveyed reported suboptimal sleep duration and low-sleep quality as assessed by the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality scale [46]. In a multivariate analysis model, the effect of sleep duration on obesity risk was rather modest, with a significant association between lower sleep quality and increased BMI in women only, and this association was modulated by perceived stress level as measured by the Cohen scale.
A sex difference in the association between poor-sleep quality and obesity risk has been confirmed in a longitudinal study of 7000 Finnish adults, aged 4060 years. In women, sleep problems (difficulty initiating and maintaining sleep) predicted weight gain after 57 years. Moreover, there was a graded effect depending on the frequency of the sleep disturbances [47].
Nordin and Kaplan [48] examined the effect of sleep discontinuity on the development of obesity over a 30-year period in approximately 7000 middle-age adults. Sleep quality was self-reported and assessed by the question how often do you have any trouble getting to sleep or staying asleep? On the basis of the answers compared from the first and last observation, the participants were divided into four categories of sleep continuity, consistently good continuity, consistent discontinuity, impaired continuity (worsened over time), and improved continuity. The main outcome was the risk of transition to and from obesity. Consistent sleep discontinuity was associated with 70% risk of conversion to obesity after adjusting for confounding variables related to demographics, pain, lifestyle, and health including sleep duration. Both consistent sleep discontinuity and impaired sleep continuity reduced the chance for transitioning from obesity, thus increasing the risk of staying obese. The major limitation of the study was that sleep quality and anthropometrics were self-reported and the analysis could not control the presence of a sleep disorder like OSA, which could in part account for the risk of weight gain.

A 30-year study has also shown that consistent sleep discontinuity is associated with a 70% risk of conversion to obesity. R: simple summary: Lack of sleep can make it harder to maintain a healthy weight, especially for people who are already very overweight. When we don't get enough good quality sleep, it can mess with our appetite and make us less likely to want to exercise. Some studies have found that people who don't sleep well tend to have a higher body mass index (BMI), but this isn't always true for older people. For women, having trouble falling asleep or staying asleep can lead to weight gain over time. And a really long study found that people who have a hard time sleeping consistently are much more likely to become obese. So it's important to make sure we're getting enough good quality sleep if we want to stay healthy and keep our weight under control.
